importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication reflects the current global context of escalating extreme weather events, underscoring the urgency of early-warning systems in response to climate change impacts.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The article focuses on recent and ongoing extreme weather events in 2025, such as floods in Pakistan, Nigeria, and South Korea, and wildfires in southern Europe and the US, highlighting the real-time relevance of the UN's call for improved early-warning systems.

keyTakeAways: Nearly half of all countries lack early-warning systems for extreme weather events, leaving millions—especially in developing nations—vulnerable.
The WMO report highlights that disaster-related deaths are six times higher in countries without early-warning systems, with 90% of deaths in the past 50 years occurring in developing countries.
Over 2 million people have died from weather, water, and climate-related hazards in the past 50 years.
While 108 countries now use some form of multi-hazard early warning systems (up from 52), half still have only basic capacity and 16% have less than basic capacity.
The situation is worst in fragile, conflict-affected, and violence-prone regions.
Progress is being made in Africa, with more countries establishing functioning websites and issuing standardized alerts.
The WMO emphasizes that early warnings enable early action and that the goal is not just to warn but to empower communities.
Real-world examples, such as the evacuation of Blatten, Switzerland, due to a predicted glacier collapse in May 2025, demonstrate the life-saving potential of early-warning systems.
Permafrost melt is expected to increase glacier collapses and rockfalls, reinforcing the global need for improved monitoring and alert systems.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The World Meteorological Organization (WMO), a UN agency, has issued a global call for improved early-warning systems for extreme weather events, warning that nearly half of all countries lack adequate monitoring and forecasting capabilities. With over 2 million deaths linked to weather, water, and climate hazards in the past 50 years—90% occurring in developing nations—the urgency is clear. Despite progress in early-warning adoption (from 52 to 108 countries), many still have only basic or insufficient systems, especially in fragile and conflict-affected areas. Real-world examples such as the evacuation of Blatten, Switzerland, in May 2025 due to a predicted glacier collapse, show the life-saving potential of early warnings. The WMO stresses that early warnings enable early action, and that empowering communities through timely alerts is essential to protecting lives and infrastructure in an era of increasingly extreme weather driven by climate change.
title: UN pushes for worldwide disaster alerts as extreme weather ‘spirals’
